name: Project Zulu
text: White sand stretches endlessly, shimmering under the warm sun. Its fine grains feel cool and soft beneath your feet. Gentle breezes carry the scent of salt and sea. The tranquil beauty invites peaceful reflection and relaxation.

name: ClickClack
text:
My friends and I wanted to explore Next.js, we wanted to build something fun. ClickClack was born.
 This typing-test prompts the user to select a difficulty and type in a theme, it then generates a text for the user to type before the time runs out!
keyPoints: ClickClack times the user and calculates stats liked words-per-minute (WPM) and more.

name: Project Vitalis
text:
I built Project Vitalis as a learning experience, to explore Go's multithreading while building something I needed.
One thread monitors PC components, while the other renders the Temrinal UI.
keyPoints: TUI made in Bubblegum and its Lipgloss library
More features to come before proper release-build!

name: AudioReaper
text:
AudioReaper is a simple Web app that makes adding the songs in your PC's library to your Spotify easy.
 It reads MP3 and WAV files' metadata and filename and searches for the songs on Spotify.
 Users are required to authorize access to their account to specify a playlist or create a new one, but NO data is collected nor stored. Zero strings attached!
keyPoints: Flask backend handles all data processing and API querries.
Waiting on Spotify to grant API quota...

name: NaqaMD
text:
Quick and powerful Markdown to HTML converter written in OCaml. This was the first Functional Programming language at BCIT, and I made this to get a solid understanding of its pattern matching and functional nature.
OCaml made Recursion click for me!
keyPoints: Not the most polished converter out there, this was a learning experience.
It did its job and I used it several times since.
Identified some bugs, but I've moved on to other projects.

name: Project ShrubGarden
text:
I write a lot in my Obsidian vault. Covering a variety of topics including Computer Scienct and Software, book summaries, to project planning. Some of what I write reads like a blog, so why not share it?
 That's precisely the plan!
keyPoints: Using an SSG like Hugo, Jykell, or Zola(Rust based btw).
My own little digital garden on the web.
